   68 y.o. F with PMHx of Breast CA, polio & newly dx secondary AML s/p
   induction with 7+3.  Post induction course complicated by febrile
   neutropenia, worsening hypoxia & ARDS. Pt transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 44**],
   intubated & s/p Bronchoscopy on [**2167-1-27**].
   # Respiratory Failure
 Pt initially p/w upper lobe PNA, initially
   improved on Abx. Then, after induction with 7+3 developped bilateral
   lower lobe infiltrates & ARDS, intubated on [**2167-1-27**].  Extensive
   infectious workup has been neg to date, on broad antibx at time of
   bronch.  Clinical picture complicated by component of volume overload,
   but infiltrates not likely [**12-27**] pulm edema alone. Tolerated PS trial
   yesterday.  Working towards extubation in next 48hrs
   - Vanc continues to be supratherapeutic, holding for now, HD yesterday
   to lower level
   - continue meropenem, levofloxacin and voriconazole
   - continue steroid taper, solumedrol from 20 mg bis to 10 mg bis today,
   then d/c tomorrow
   -  f/u ID recs
   -  f/u pending culture data
   -  difficult to diurese, 2.5L taken off by HD, catheter now pulled
   - repeat b-glucan
   - cont to diurese, will try lasix, chlorthiazide and albumin
   - goal net negative 1L
   - cont on pressure support trials with goal of possibel extubation
   tomorrow
   # AML:  Day 28 s/p induction with 7+3. Neutropenic, monos return on
   diff from [**1-30**] e/o marrow reconstitution
   - transfusion scales: transfuse if Hct<25 or plt<10
   - monitor daily ANCs , still neutropenic but ANC rising.   Avoiding
   G-CSF.
   - will not repeat bone marrow biopsy at this time
   - f/u BMT rec
   # ARF
 pt with rising BUN/Creatinine & [**Month (only) 38**] UOP. Muddy brown casts in
   urinary sediment consistent with ATN, etiology unclear.   Creatinine
   plateau not defined yet, waiting on resolution.  UOP did not respond
   approp to Lasix 120mg challenge. Potassium down to normal range from
   5.1, but no EKG changes noted.   Pt required HD x1 [**2-2**] for elevated
   vanc level is setting of renal failure and marrow suppression.  2.5L
   removed.  HD catheter removed after the one use.
   - appreciate renal rec
   - cont phos binders
   # Afib
 new, started [**2-2**] following insertion of the HD catheter,
   likely due to atrial irritation.  Titrated up on a dilt gtt, now well
   controlled in sinus on po meds.  Will follow.
   - continue current regimen
   # Anemia
 has been transfusion dependant s/p induction, received 2u
   pRBCs on [**1-30**] from hct of 20.  Post transfusion hct has been stable at
   29, no obvious source of bleeding.  Marrow beginning to reconstitute.
   Reeived Eop with HD
   - transfusion to maintain hct >25
   - stool guaiac negative
   - hemolysis labs negative
   # Mental Status changes
 MS changes noted on day prior to intubation.
   CT Head negative for evidence of bleed. No clear evidence of metastatic
   disease or emboli. However, given initial path significant for M4 AML
   which is known for CNS spread. Consider toxic/metabolic/hypoxia &
   polypharmacy as most likely etiology of MS changes.
   - continue to renally dose meds, treat hypoxia .
   -will be able to better evaluate when patient extubated, will consider
   MRI if MS [**First Name (Titles) 292**] [**Last Name (Titles) 1479**]

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3. She was intubated due to respiratory failure and has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient has developed bilateral lower lobe infiltrates and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and her clinical picture is complicated by component of volume overload. She has been tolerating pressure support trials and is working towards extubation in the next 48 hours.

The patient has also developed atrial fibrillation, which is well-controlled on diltiazem. She has been transfusion-dependent for anemia and has received two units of packed red blood cells. Her mental status has changed, and a CT head was negative for evidence of bleed or metastatic disease.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and she may require continued respiratory support.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is rising, and she has developed muddy brown casts in her urinary sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is well-controlled on diltiazem, but it may require further management.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is transfusion-dependent, and she may require further transfusions to maintain a hemoglobin level of 25%.
5. Mental status changes: The patient's mental status has changed, and it may be related to toxic, metabolic, or hypoxic causes.
6. Central nervous system (CNS) involvement: The patient's AML is known to have CNS spread, and she may require further evaluation and treatment for CNS involvement.

Recommendations:

1. Continue respiratory support and pressure support trials to optimize lung function.
2. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and urinary output closely, and consider further management of AKI.
3. Continue atrial fibrillation management with diltiazem and monitor for any changes in her rhythm.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfusion requirements, and consider further evaluation for any underlying causes.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and consider further evaluation and treatment for CNS involvement.
6. Consider further evaluation and treatment for CNS involvement, including MRI and lumbar puncture.

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of stage II breast cancer, polio, and post-polio syndrome, who was recently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and started on chemotherapy. She was transferred to the ICU for progressive hypoxemia, intubated for respiratory failure, and diagnosed with ARDS. She has been experiencing fevers, lung infiltrates, and acute kidney injury (ARF). Her laboratory results show anemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia, which have been managed with dialysis and diuresis. She is neutropenic and has a high vancomycin level.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Respiratory failure with ARDS: The patient's respiratory status is stable, and she is expected to be extubated in the next 1-2 days. She will be tapered off steroids and will receive diuresis and oxygen therapy as needed.
2. ARF: The patient's renal function is improving, and she will continue to receive dialysis as needed.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chemotherapy and renal failure. She will continue to receive blood transfusions as needed.
4. Hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia: These electrolyte imbalances have been resolved with dialysis and diuresis.
5. AML/Chemotherapy: The patient's chemotherapy regimen will continue, and she will be monitored for any signs of bone marrow toxicity.
6. Neutropenia: The patient's neutropenia is being managed with broad-spectrum antibiotics and will continue until her ANC improves.
7. Lines: The patient has new PICC and R IJ dialysis catheters inserted.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status could deteriorate further, leading to respiratory failure.
2. ARF: The patient's renal function could worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
3. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing further infections, particularly in her neutropenic state.
4. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to her anemia and platelet count.
5. Bone marrow toxicity: The patient's chemotherapy regimen could cause bone marrow toxicity, leading to further anemia and neutropenia.
6. Hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia: These electrolyte imbalances could recur if the patient's kidney function does not improve.
7. Line-related complications: The patient is at risk for line-related complications, such as infection, bleeding, and thrombosis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3. She is currently intubated in the ICU with respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (AKI), and atrial fibrillation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 104 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 155/78 mmHg. She is receiving oxygen therapy at 40% and has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 0.5 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 88 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 112 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: potassium 4.2 mEq/L, magnesium 1.8 mg/dL, phosphate 4.8 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 508 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 4.8 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Mild interval worsening of left lower lung opacities with obscuration of the left hemidiaphragm
* Bilateral diffuse opacities are stable
* Small left pleural effusion
* Cardiomediastinal contours are unchanged

The patient's clinical picture is complicated by component of volume overload with a B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level >1527 normal upper limit of normal, but infiltrates are not likely pulmonary edema alone. She is tolerating pressure support with PEEP now down to 5 cmH2O and FiO2 40%. The goal is to extubate the patient in the next 48 hours.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
* AKI: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and there is a risk of further worsening of kidney function.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is not well-controlled, and there is a risk of further complications.
* Anemia: The patient is transfusion-dependent and at risk of further anemia.
* Mental status changes: The patient has had mental status changes, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
* Infection: The patient has had a broad-spectrum antibiotic regimen, and there is a risk of further infection.
* Volume overload: The patient has had a component of volume overload, and there is a risk of further worsening of this condition.

Based on the patient's clinical picture, it is recommended to:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
* Continue to manage the patient's AKI with diuretics and hemodialysis as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust therapy as necessary.
* Continue to transfuse the patient as necessary to maintain a hemoglobin level >25.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust therapy as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust therapy as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient for signs of volume overload and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who underwent induction with 7+3. She developed febrile neutropenia, worsening hypoxia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) requiring intubation. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (AKI), atrial fibrillation (Afib), anemia, and mental status changes.

The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, with a decrease in PEEP from 8 to 5 cmH2O and a FiO2 of 40%. However, she still requires mechanical ventilation. Her fluid balance is a concern, with a net fluid intake of 1,182 mL and output of 894 mL over the past 24 hours. She has been on diuretics, but has not responded well, with a poor response to lasix/thiazide/albumin yesterday.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 0.5, hemoglobin of 10.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 88. Her creatinine level is elevated at 2.6 mg/dL, and she has muddy brown casts in her urinary sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Her BUN/Creatinine ratio is rising, and she has been on hemodialysis (HD) once already.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a normal ejection fraction (EF) and no signs of pulmonary edema. She has been on anticoagulation therapy for atrial fibrillation, which has been well-controlled.

The patient's mental status has been stable, with no evidence of bleeding or metastatic disease. However, she has been experiencing mental status changes, which are thought to be due to toxic, metabolic, hypoxic, or polypharmacy-related causes.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. AKI: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she has muddy brown casts in her urinary sediment consistent with ATN. She may require further hemodialysis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which may require further anticoagulation therapy.
4. Mental status changes: The patient's mental status has been stable, but she may experience further changes due to toxic, metabolic, hypoxic, or polypharmacy-related causes.
5. Infection: The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics, but she may still be at risk for infection due to her neutropenia.
6. Bleeding: The patient has been transfusion-dependent, and she may be at risk for bleeding due to her thrombocytopenia.
7. Organ dysfunction: The patient's kidneys and liver may be at risk for further dysfunction due to her underlying disease and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of stage II breast cancer, polio, and post-polio syndrome, who was recently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). She was started on chemotherapy and developed fevers, lung infiltrates, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). She was intubated and transferred to the ICU for progressive hypoxemia and respiratory failure. Despite being off steroids, she remains hypoxemic and has not responded to diuretics. She has acute kidney injury (AKI) and is oliguric, with a mixed pre-renal and atn picture. Her creatinine is increasing, and she was dialyzed for elevated vancomycin levels. She has anemia, neutropenia, and is at risk for volume overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and ARDS may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. AKI: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and she is oliguric, which may indicate a worsening of AKI. This may lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and increased risk of mortality.
3. Infection: The patient has a history of fevers, lung infiltrates, and ARDS, which may indicate an underlying infection. This may lead to further complications, such as sepsis, organ failure, and increased risk of mortality.
4. Volume overload: The patient's fluid balance is a concern, and she may be at risk for volume overload, which may lead to further complications, such as pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, and increased risk of mortality.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further complications, such as decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, increased risk of infection, and decreased immune function.
6. Neutropenia: The patient's neutropenia may worsen, leading to further complications, such as increased risk of infection, sepsis, and organ failure.
7. Line-related complications: The patient has multiple lines, including an arterial line, PICC line, and dialysis catheter, which may be at risk for complications, such as bleeding, infection, and thrombosis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust dialysis settings as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust fluid management as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and adjust antimicrobial therapy as needed.
5. Consider repeating BM bx to assess response to chemotherapy.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust transfusion therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's neutropenia and adjust antimicrobial therapy as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's lines for complications and adjust management as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3. She is currently intubated and has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (ARF), and atrial fibrillation.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.5C (97.7F)
* Heart rate: 101 bpm (normal range: 72-101 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 136/90 mmHg (normal range: 105/63-158/100 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 inspirations per minute (normal range: 18-33 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 94% (normal range: 95-100%)

The patient has been on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, set at 400 mL and 15 cmH2O, with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 50%. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.48, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 31 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 128 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 0.5 x 10^9/L (normal range: 4.5-11.0 x 10^9/L)
* Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL (normal range: 12.0-16.0 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 104 x 10^9/L (normal range: 150-450 x 10^9/L)
* Creatinine: 2.6 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.1 mg/dL)
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 38 mg/dL (normal range: 7-20 mg/dL)

The patient has a history of febrile neutropenia, worsening hypoxia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which led to her admission to the ICU. She has also had a recent episode of atrial fibrillation, which was likely caused by atrial irritation from the insertion of the hemodialysis catheter.

The patient's current medications include:

* Meropenem: 1 g every 8 hours
* Voriconazole: 200 mg every 12 hours
* Vancomycin: 1 g every 12 hours
* Hydrocortisone: 100 mg every 8 hours
* Lasix: 40 mg every 8 hours
* Phosphate binders: 2 tablets every 12 hours

The patient's plan includes:

* Hemodialysis today to facilitate extubation
* Continued meropenem and voriconazole therapy
* Monitoring of white blood cell count and platelet count
* Transfusion of blood products as needed
* Continued treatment of atrial fibrillation with diltiazem
* Monitoring of electrolyte levels and glucose control

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and further worsening of kidney function could lead to acute kidney injury.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation could worsen and lead to cardiac complications.
* Infection: The patient's neutropenia and immunosuppressive therapy make her susceptible to infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and recent transfusions make her at risk for bleeding complications.
* Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia could worsen and lead to respiratory failure or other complications.

   - transfusion scales: transfuse if Hct<25 or plt<10
   - monitor daily ANCs , no longer neutropenic  Avoiding G-CSF.
   - f/u BMT rec
   # ARF
 pt with rising BUN/Creatinine & [**Month (only) 38**] UOP. Muddy brown casts in
   urinary sediment consistent with ATN, etiology unclear.   Creatinine
   plateau not defined yet, waiting on resolution.  UOP did not respond
   approp to Lasix/thiazide/albumin. No Longer hyperkalemic.   Pt required
   HD x1 [**2-2**] for elevated vanc level is setting of renal failure and
   marrow suppression.  2.5L removed.  HD catheter removed after the one
   use.  Pt oliguric yesterday and concern that patient could have
   worsened volume overload comprimising respiration after extubation.  HD
   catheter yesterday placed, but was not dialyzed.  Planed for HD today,
   but patient now making urine.
   - plan  for HD today
   - appreciate renal rec
   - cont phos binders, increased yesterday
    # Afib
 new, started [**2-2**] following insertion of the HD catheter,
   likely due to atrial irritation.  Was temporary controlled on dilt gtt,
   now well controlled in sinus on po meds.  Will follow.
   - continue current regimen
   # Anemia
 has been transfusion dependant s/p induction, received 2u
   pRBCs on [**1-30**] from hct of 20.  Post transfusion hct has been stable at
   29, no obvious source of bleeding.  Marrow beginning to reconstitute.
   Received Eop with HD
   - transfusion to maintain hct >25
   - stool guaiac negative
   - hemolysis labs negative
   # Mental Status changes
 MS changes noted on day prior to intubation.
   CT Head negative for evidence of bleed. No clear evidence of metastatic
   disease or emboli. However, given initial path significant for M4 AML
   which is known for CNS spread. Consider toxic/metabolic/hypoxia &
   polypharmacy as most likely etiology of MS changes.
    -continue to renally dose meds, treat hypoxia .
   -will be able to better evaluate when patient extubated, will consider
   MRI if MS [**First Name (Titles) 292**] [**Last Name (Titles) 1479**]

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3. She is currently intubated and has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and acute kidney injury (AKI).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5C, heart rate of 101 bpm, blood pressure of 136/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. She has a respiratory rate of 26 inspirations per minute and is receiving mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 104 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) of 10.8 g/dL, and platelet count (PLT) of 124 mg/dL. Her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating AKI. Her electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 26 mEq/L and a phosphorus level of 6.9 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show diffuse interstitial pulmonary abnormality with areas of consolidative coalescence, consistent with ARDS. Her chest X-ray also shows worsening fluid overload in an oliguric patient.

The patient's medical plan includes ongoing treatment with meropenem and voriconazole for suspected fungal infection, as well as steroids for reactive pneumonitis. She is also receiving dialysis therapy for AKI and is being monitored for signs of bleeding and infection.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and respiratory failure may lead to worsening hypoxia and respiratory acidosis, which can be life-threatening.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's AKI may progress to chronic kidney disease or require ongoing dialysis therapy.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and ongoing antibiotics may increase the risk of infection, including sepsis and pneumonia.
4. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and ongoing dialysis therapy may increase the risk of bleeding, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's elevated blood pressure and ongoing dialysis therapy may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrest and stroke.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's ongoing sedation and mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of neurological complications, including seizures and cognitive impairment.

Based on the patient's condition and medical plan, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to detect any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent worsening of her condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of stage II breast cancer, polio, and post-polio syndrome, who was recently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and started on chemotherapy. She was admitted to the ICU for progressive hypoxemia and respiratory failure, and was intubated for respiratory failure. She has been experiencing fevers, LUL pneumonia, volume overload, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and anemia. Her laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 10.4 g/dL, and her blood cultures have been negative. She has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and is now non-neutropenic and afebrile.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.2C (98.9F)
* Heart rate: 100 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 136/74 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 inspirations per minute (ipm)
* Oxygen saturation: 91%
* SpO2: 91%

Her physical examination shows:

* General appearance: Overweight/obese
* Head, ears, nose, and throat: Endotracheal tube and oral gastric tube
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Peripheral vascular: No radial pulses assessed
* Respiratory/chest: Crackles at the bases
* Abdominal: Soft and non-tender
* Extremities: Right: 2+, Left: 2+
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Not assessed

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 0.5-1.0 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 30.7-31.2%
* Platelet count: 88-114 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.6-3.9 mg/dL
* Total CO2: 31-28 mmHg
* Glucose: 112-124 mg/dL
* Other laboratory results: Normal or abnormal values for various electrolytes, liver enzymes, and renal function tests.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and she may require dialysis.
3. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and she may require blood transfusions.
4. Infection: The patient has a history of fevers and pneumonia, and may be at risk for further infections.
5. Steroid-responsive pneumonitis: The patient's respiratory failure may be related to a steroid-responsive pneumonitis, and she may require corticosteroids.
6. Hyperphosphatemia: The patient's phosphate levels are elevated, and she may require phosphate binders or other treatments to manage this complication.
7. Muddy brown casts on urinalysis: The patient's urinalysis shows muddy brown casts, which may indicate a mixed pre-renal atn picture.
8. ARDS: The patient's respiratory failure may be related to ARDS, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation and other supportive therapies.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and respiratory support as needed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Consider dialysis for AKI and hyperphosphatemia.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider blood transfusions as necessary.
5. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and monitor for signs of infection.
6. Consider corticosteroids for steroid-responsive pneumonitis.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Consider phosphate binders or other treatments for hyperphosphatemia.
9. Monitor the patient's urinalysis and adjust therapy as necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's overall condition and adjust therapy as necessary.

   68 y.o. F with PMHx of Breast CA, polio & newly dx secondary AML s/p
   induction with 7+3.  Post induction course complicated by febrile
   neutropenia, worsening hypoxia & ARDS. Pt transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 44**],
   intubated & s/p Bronchoscopy on [**2167-1-27**].
   # Respiratory Failure
 Pt initially p/w upper lobe PNA, initially
   improved on Abx. Then, after induction with 7+3 developed bilateral
   lower lobe infiltrates & ARDS, intubated on [**2167-1-27**].  Extensive
   infectious workup has been neg to date, on broad spectrum abx.  [**Month (only) 60**] be
   [**12-27**] to reactive pneumonitis, as had responded to steroids.  Clinical
   picture complicated by component of volume overload w/ BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 1527**]
   normal EF, but infiltrates not likely [**12-27**] pulm edema alone.
   - Vanc (day 1 [**1-15**]) continues to be supratherapeutic, holding for now,
   despite HD, still remains elevated
   -  Patient no longer neutrapenic, and levofloxacin and vori had been
   d/c
d, however, BMT would like to keep all antibiotics on until not
   neutropenic for 7 days and off the vent.  Vori restarted and
   subsequently LVQ also restarted [**12-27**] persistent fevers.
   - steroids started for reactive pneumonitis now tapered off
   - Has done well on pressure support w/ PEEP now down to 8 and FIO2 50%
   (increased from 40% overnight.)   Will attempt to extubate
   today/tomorrow with aggressive vent weaning.
   - While patient rapid RR contributing to alkalosis, some secondary
   metabolic process also contributing to alkalemia likely contraction.
   # Fever
 new infection v re-engraftment
   - cont broad spectrum antibiotics
 vanc, vori, [**Last Name (un) 430**]
   - restart levo
   - f/u cx
   # AML:  Day 29 s/p induction with 7+3. No longer neutrapecic
   - transfusion scales: transfuse if Hct<25 or plt<10
   - monitor daily ANCs , no longer neutropenic  Avoiding G-CSF.
   - f/u BMT rec
   # Mixed Metabolic Alkalosis/Respiratory Alkalosis
 following HD
   patient again became quite alkalemic, likely a contraction effect [**12-27**]
   to taking large volume of fluid off, however, does not explain ABG, pt
   also has a second componenet of respiratory alkalosis likely [**12-27**]
   hyperventilation with RR>30.
   - for metabolic alk
 likely contraction, no intervention, will follow
   gases
   - for resp
 titrate vent to decrease RR, inc sedation if necessary
   # ARF
 pt with rising BUN/Creatinine & [**Month (only) 38**] UOP. Muddy brown casts in
   urinary sediment consistent with ATN, etiology unclear.   Creatinine
   plateau not defined yet, waiting on resolution.  UOP did not respond
   approp to Lasix/thiazide/albumin. No Longer hyperkalemic.   Pt required
   HD x2 for elevated vanc level is setting of renal failure and marrow
   suppression.  2.5L removed.  Pt became oliguric with oncern that
   patient could have worsened volume overload comprimising respiration
   after extubation.  HD catheter  placed and pt dialyzed.  Patient
   currelty making urine ~30cc/h

   - cont phos binders, increased yesterday
    # Afib
 new, started [**2-2**] following insertion of the HD catheter,
   likely due to atrial irritation.  Was temporary controlled on dilt gtt,
   now well controlled in sinus on po meds.  Will follow.
   - continue current regimen
   # Anemia
 has been transfusion dependant s/p induction, received 2u
   pRBCs on [**1-30**] from hct of 20.  Post transfusion hct has been stable at
   29, no obvious source of bleeding.  Marrow beginning to reconstitute.
   Received Eop with HD

   # Mental Status changes
 MS changes noted on day prior to intubation.
   CT Head negative for evidence of bleed. No clear evidence of metastatic
   disease or emboli. However, given initial path significant for M4 AML
   which is known for CNS spread. Consider toxic/metabolic/hypoxia &
   polypharmacy as most likely etiology of MS changes.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has a fever, which has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, and has undergone hemodialysis (HD) for elevated vancomycin levels and volume overload. She has also developed anemia and requires transfusions. The patient's mental status has changed, and a CT head scan was negative for evidence of bleed or metastatic disease.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration due to her underlying lung disease and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and ongoing antibiotic therapy suggest a possible infection, which may be related to the underlying AML or a new infection.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's rising BUN and creatinine levels, along with muddy brown casts in the urinary sediment, suggest acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This may be related to the vancomycin toxicity or underlying AML.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to the underlying AML and may require further transfusions.
5. Mental Status Changes: The patient's mental status changes may be related to the underlying AML, hypoxia, or polypharmacy, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Volume Overload: The patient's volume overload, as evidenced by her BNP levels and fluid balance, may require further management to prevent further respiratory compromise.
7. Antibiotic-Resistant Infection: The patient's ongoing antibiotic therapy and lack of response to treatment suggest a possible antibiotic-resistant infection.
8. Bleeding Risk: The patient's anemia and ongoing transfusions may increase her risk of bleeding.
9. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and possible cardiac irritability may increase her risk of cardiac complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Consider further evaluation and treatment of the patient's fever, including repeat cultures and consideration of alternative antibiotics.
3. Continue to manage the patient's volume overload through diuretics and fluid restriction.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider further treatment options for ATN.
5. Continue to manage the patient's anemia through transfusions and consideration of growth factors.
6. Evaluate the patient's mental status changes further and consider further treatment options, such as MRI.
7. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk closely and consider further treatment options, such as platelet transfusions.
8. Consider further cardiac evaluation and treatment options, such as cardioversion, for the patient's atrial fibrillation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3. She was transferred to the ICU due to febrile neutropenia, worsening hypoxia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 310 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. Her oxygen saturation is 92%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a tachycardic rhythm with a heart rate of 108 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 149/63 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient has a central venous catheter and is receiving vasopressors.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 2.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 32 mg/dL. She is oliguric and requires hemodialysis (HD).
* Neurological status: The patient has mental status changes and is sedated.
* Infectious status: The patient has a fever and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. She has a negative infectious workup to date.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardic rhythm and hypertension may indicate cardiac instability.
* Renal failure: The patient's AKI may progress to chronic kidney disease or require long-term dialysis.
* Infection: The patient's fever and neutropenia may increase her risk of developing a secondary infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase her risk of bleeding.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's mental status changes may progress to more severe neurological dysfunction.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Hemodialysis to manage AKI
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat suspected infection
* Vasopressors to manage hypotension
* Sedation to manage agitation and anxiety
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure, cardiovascular instability, and renal failure
* Evaluation for signs of infection and bleeding
* Consideration of MRI to evaluate for central nervous system (CNS) involvement in the patient's AML.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of stage II breast cancer, polio, and post-polio syndrome. She was recently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and started chemotherapy. She was admitted to the ICU due to progressive hypoxemia, respiratory failure, and ARDS. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.5F (38.6C)
* Heart rate: 88-118 bpm
* Blood pressure: 109/52 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 93%
* WBC count: 0.9-1.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 104-114 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.4-3.9 mg/dL
* BUN: 32-34 mg/dL
* Glucose: 124-113 mg/dL

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Positive blood cultures for vancomycin
* Elevated vancomycin levels
* Abnormal liver function tests (ALT/AST)
* Abnormal kidney function tests (creatinine/BUN)
* Abnormal electrolyte levels (Na+/K+/Cl-)
* Abnormal coagulation tests (PT/PTT/INR)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* ARDS
* Respiratory failure
* Anemia
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Infection (sepsis)
* Pneumonia
* Steroid-responsive pneumonitis
* Post-polio syndrome

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* ARDS
* Respiratory failure
* Anemia
* AKI
* Infection (bacteremia)
* Pneumothorax
* Pulmonary embolism
* Cardiac arrest
* Hypotension
* Hypoxemia
* Hypercapnia

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotics (meropenem, voriconazole, vancomycin)
* Dialysis
* Chemotherapy (AML treatment)
* Fluid management
* Pain management
* Nutritional support
* Glycemic control
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Management of mechanical ventilation
* Monitoring of fluid balance and electrolyte levels
* Management of pain and discomfort
* Nutritional support
* Glycemic control
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Daily wake-up and mouth care to prevent VAP.

   Assessment and Plan
   68 y.o. F with PMHx of Breast CA, polio & newly dx secondary AML s/p
   induction with 7+3.  Post induction course complicated by febrile
   neutropenia, worsening hypoxia & ARDS. Pt transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 44**],
   intubated & s/p Bronchoscopy on [**2167-1-27**].
   # Respiratory Failure
 Pt initially p/w upper lobe PNA, improved on
   Abx. Then, after induction with 7+3 developed bilateral lower lobe
   infiltrates & ARDS, intubated on [**2167-1-27**].  Extensive infectious workup
   has been neg to date, on broad spectrum abx.  [**Month (only) 60**] be [**12-27**] to reactive
   pneumonitis, as it had responded to steroids.  Clinical picture
   complicated by component of volume overload w/ BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 1527**] normal EF,
   but infiltrates not likely [**12-27**] pulm edema alone.  Pt  tolerated PS but
   persistently tachypneic, RSBI in 80s today, pO2 in 70s.
   - continue Vancomycin, [**Last Name (un) **], Levo, Vori (will recheck vanc level after
   HD & dose accordingly)
   - steroids started for reactive pneumonitis now tapered off
   - rapid RR contributing to alkalosis, ?some secondary metabolic process
   also contributing to alkalemia
   - continue to work towards extubation, addl volume removal via HD,
   reassess ABG after HD
   # Fever
  unclear if this is due to new infection vs re-engraftment.
   Cultures have been NGTD, line site looks good.  Pt may need CT to r/o
   sinusitis vs new pulm process.  Pt spiked this afternoon and was
   re-cultured.
   - cont broad spectrum antibiotics
 vanc, voriconazole, [**Last Name (un) 430**] & levo
   - f/u cultures, consider CT in am
   - consider lower extremity dopplers to r/o DVT
   # AML:  Day 30 s/p induction with 7+3. Counts recovering, no longer
   neutropenic
   - transfusion scales: transfuse if Hct<25 or plt<10
   - monitor daily ANCs , avoiding G-CSF.
   - f/u BMT rec
   # Mixed Metabolic Alkalosis/Respiratory Alkalosis
pt continues to have
   a respiratory alkalosis [**12-27**] hyperventilation with RR>30.  Etiology
   unclear currently, maintaining pO2 in 70s and working towards
   extubation, but RSBI was high on [**2-6**] & still trying to remove volume
   via HD.  Pt having fevers that may also be contributing to tachypneic
   drive
   - for resp alkalosis
 follow ABGs titrate vent prn decrease RR, inc
   sedation if necessary
    # ARF
Rising Creatine & muddy brown casts in sediment consistent with
   ATN.   Creatinine plateau not defined yet, still waiting on
   resolution.  UOP did not respond to Lasix/thiazide/albumin. Pt became
   oliguric and concern that patient with worsened volume overload
   comprimising ability to extubate, HD catheter placed and pt has been
   getting dialyzed for supratherapeutic Vanc levels per renal.
   - plan for HD today, 1upRBCs after HD
   - appreciate renal rec
   - cont phos binders
    # Afib
started [**2-2**] following insertion of the HD catheter, likely
   due to atrial irritation.  HR was temporary controlled on dilt gtt, now
   well controlled in sinus on po meds.
   - continue diltiazem
   # Anemia
 has been transfusion dependant s/p induction, received 2u
   pRBCs on [**1-30**] from hct of 20.  Hct trended down o/n from 29.8 to 24.9,
   will recheck hct after HD and if stable below 25, will transfuse
   1upRBCs
    - transfusion goal to maintain hct >25
   - stool guaiac negative
   - hemolysis labs negative
   # Mental Status changes
 MS changes noted on day prior to intubation.
   CT Head neg, however, M4 AML is known for CNS spread that may not be
   appreciable on CT.  Hypoxia & polypharmacy most likely etiology of MS
   changes prior to intubation & unable to properly assess MS [**First Name (Titles) 1646**]
[**Last Name (Titles) 1647**]ted.
   - better evaluate when pt extubated, consider MRI if MS [**First Name (Titles) 292**] [**Last Name (Titles) 1479**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nutren Pulm 45ml/hr
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who underwent induction therapy with 7+3. The patient developed febrile neutropenia, worsening hypoxia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) requiring intubation and bronchoscopy.

Current status:

* Respiratory: The patient has bilateral lower lobe infiltrates and ARDS, with a respiratory rate (RR) of 23 breaths per minute, and a partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 168 mmHg on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a heart rate (HR) of 104 beats per minute, with a blood pressure (BP) of 162/72 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient has rising creatinine levels and muddy brown casts in the sediment, consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* Hematological: The patient has anemia, with a hemoglobin (Hb) level of 8.6 g/dL, and is transfusion-dependent.
* Metabolic: The patient has mixed metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis, with a serum bicarbonate level of 24 mmol/L and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 32 mmHg.
* Infectious: The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, levo, and voriconazole, with ongoing fevers and a negative infectious workup.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and bilateral lower lobe infiltrates may progress, leading to further respiratory failure.
* Renal failure: The patient's ATN may worsen, leading to further kidney damage and potential end-stage renal disease.
* Infection: The patient's ongoing fevers and negative infectious workup may indicate a new or persistent infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and ongoing transfusions may increase the risk of bleeding.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as atrial fibrillation and cardiac arrhythmias.

Plan:

* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for ongoing fevers.
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure, including decreased oxygen saturation and increased RR.
* Continue renal replacement therapy (RRT) for ATN and supratherapeutic vancomycin levels.
* Monitor for signs of bleeding, including decreased platelet count and increased bleeding risk.
* Continue cardiac monitoring for signs of cardiac complications, including atrial fibrillation and cardiac arrhythmias.
* Consider MRI for further evaluation of the patient's mental status changes.

   likely due to atrial irritation.  Was temporary controlled on dilt gtt,
   now well controlled in sinus on po meds.  Will follow.

   pRBCs on [**1-30**] from hct of 20.  Hct drop o/n from 29.8 to 24.9, no
   obvious source of bleeding.  Marrow beginning to reconstitute.
   - transfuse with 1upRBCs today, goal to maintain hct >25
   - stool guaiac negative
   - hemolysis labs negative
   # Mental Status changes
 MS changes noted on day prior to intubation.
   CT Head negative for evidence of bleed. No clear evidence of metastatic
   disease or emboli. However, given initial path significant for M4 AML
   which is known for CNS spread. Consider toxic/metabolic/hypoxia &
   polypharmacy as most likely etiology of MS changes.
    -continue to renally dose meds, treat hypoxia .

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who was induced with 7+3 chemotherapy. She developed febrile neutropenia, worsening hypoxia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) requiring intubation. She has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and an extensive infectious workup has been negative to date.

Current Status:

The patient is still intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate (RR) of 23 inspirations per minute. She has a high respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) and is unable to tolerate pressure support. Her blood pressure (BP) is 162/72 mmHg, and her oxygen saturation (SpO2) is 95%. She has a white blood cell count (WBC) of 1.1 K/uL and a platelet count (PLT) of 116 K/uL.

Laboratory Results:

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.6 g/dL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 29.9%
* Creatinine (Cr): 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): [not reported]
* Potassium (K): 26 mEq/L
* Sodium (Na): 139 mEq/L
* Chloride (Cl): 100 mEq/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* LDH: 508 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus (PO4): 6.3 mg/dL

Medical Complications:

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: She has ARDS and is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
2. Fever: She has persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotics, and cultures are pending to rule out new infections.
3. AML: She is in remission, but her bone marrow is still suppressed.
4. Anemia: She has been transfusion-dependent and has a low hemoglobin level.
5. ARF: She has rising BUN and creatinine levels, and muddy brown casts in her urinary sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
6. Afib: She has new-onset atrial fibrillation (Afib) likely due to atrial irritation from the hemodialysis catheter.
7. Mixed metabolic alkalosis/respiratory alkalosis: She has a high bicarbonate level and a respiratory alkalosis likely due to hyperventilation.

Plan:

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics until she is no longer neutropenic for 7 days and off the ventilator.
2. Restarting levofloxacin and voriconazole.
3. Monitoring her respiratory status and adjusting her ventilator settings as needed.
4. Transfusing packed red blood cells (pRBCs) to maintain a hemoglobin level >25%.
5. Continuing hemodialysis (HD) for her acute kidney injury (AKI).
6. Monitoring her mental status changes and adjusting her medication regimen as needed.
7. Considering an MRI if her mental status changes persist after extubation.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old woman with a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), who is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure and acute kidney injury (AKI). She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C (98.9F), heart rate of 103 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 165/73 mmHg. She is receiving dialysis and has a substantial vancomycin level.

The patient has a history of breast cancer, post-polio syndrome, and recent diagnosis of AML, which was treated with 7+3 induction chemotherapy. She is currently being followed by the bone marrow transplant service.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and she requires continued mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. AKI: The patient's AKI is likely to continue, and she will require ongoing dialysis to manage her fluid and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Infection: The patient's fever and respiratory failure suggest the possibility of an underlying infection, which needs to be investigated and treated promptly.
4. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated, and she may be at risk for hemodynamic instability, particularly if her blood pressure drops further.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and she may require blood transfusions to manage her anemia.
6. AML relapse: The patient's AML is a significant concern, and she may be at risk for relapse, particularly if her bone marrow is not adequately cleared of residual disease.
7. Organ dysfunction: The patient's respiratory and renal dysfunction may lead to organ dysfunction in other systems, such as cardiovascular or gastrointestinal systems.

Given the patient's critical illness, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of her respiratory and renal function, as well as her infection risk and potential for hemodynamic instability.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old woman with a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), post-polio syndrome, and breast cancer, who is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure and acute renal failure. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, as well as dialysis.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.2C (98.9F)
* Heart rate: 103 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 165/73 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 93%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Sinus tachycardia

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 1.3 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 29.8%
* Platelet count: 95 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26 mg/dL
* Glucose: 113 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: normal
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L

The patient's medication list includes:

* Levofloxacin
* Voriconazole
* Meropenem
* Propofol
* Lansoprazole
* Peridex
* RISS
* Diltiazem

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General appearance: No acute distress, intubated
* Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds
* Respiratory: Rhonchorous breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender
* Neurologic: Sedated, no movement or tone

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and there is a risk of further kidney damage.
* Infection: The patient's fever and respiratory failure may be related to an infection, and there is a risk of sepsis.
* Anemia: The patient's hematocrit level is low, and there is a risk of further anemia.
* Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, and there is a risk of bleeding.

Based on this information, the patient's care plan should focus on:

* Managing the patient's respiratory status, including adjusting ventilation settings and monitoring for signs of respiratory failure.
* Continuing dialysis and monitoring the patient's creatinine level.
* Managing the patient's fever and infection, including restarting antibiotics and monitoring for signs of sepsis.
* Monitoring the patient's anemia and bleeding risk, including transfusing blood products as needed.
* Continuously monitoring the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to adjust the care plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old woman with a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.2C (98.9F)
* Heart rate: 103 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 165/73 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 93%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 1.3 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 95 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26 mg/dL
* Sodium: 139 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.2 mmol/L
* Chloride: 100 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 6.3 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 508 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.8 mg/dL
* Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL
* PO4: 6.3 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes breast cancer, post-polio syndrome, and recent diagnosis of AML. She has undergone 7+3 chemotherapy and is currently in the ICU with respiratory failure and AKI.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further deterioration of her condition.
2. AKI: The patient's AKI may progress, leading to further decline in her renal function.
3. Infection: The patient's fevers may be indicative of an underlying infection, which could spread to other parts of her body.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fevers and tachycardia may be indicative of sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase her risk of bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further decline in her oxygen-carrying capacity.
7. AML relapse: The patient's AML may relapse, leading to further treatment challenges.

Based on the patient's condition, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation to support the patient's respiratory function.
2. Continue dialysis to manage the patient's AKI.
3. Administer antibiotics to treat the patient's suspected infection.
4. Monitor the patient's blood counts and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Consider further imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) scans, to evaluate the patient's condition.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation and ventilation status, and adjust treatment as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3 chemotherapy. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 102.2F (39C)
* Heart rate: 104 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 139/69 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 inspirations per minute (IPM)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 1.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 116 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: sodium 140 mmol/L, potassium 4.1 mmol/L, chloride 27.7 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): diffuse patchy airspace opacities, worse on the left than on the right
* Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head and sinuses: not available

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure and ARDS
* Fever, possibly due to new infection or re-engraftment
* Mixed metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) with rising creatinine and muddy brown casts in sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
* Atrial fibrillation (AFib) likely due to atrial irritation from the hemodialysis (HD) catheter
* Anemia, transfusion-dependent
* Mental status changes, possibly due to hypoxia, polypharmacy, and CNS spread of M4 AML

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and monitor for new infections
* Continue HD and adjust fluid removal as needed
* Titrate ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation and reduce respiratory alkalosis
* Monitor for signs of volume overload and adjust fluid management accordingly
* Consider CT scan of the sinuses and chest to evaluate for worsening of ARDS or development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Continue to work towards extubation and weaning from mechanical ventilation

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Worsening of ARDS or development of VAP
* Further decline in renal function or development of chronic kidney disease
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Worsening of anemia or development of bleeding due to coagulopathy
* Development of mental status changes or seizures due to electrolyte imbalances or medication side effects
* Increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to electrolyte imbalances or medication side effects.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) following induction with 7+3. She is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure, febrile neutropenia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and has bilateral lower lobe infiltrates and ARDS. She is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and the etiology of her respiratory failure is unclear.
2. Fever: The patient has an unclear etiology of her fever, which may be due to a new infection or re-engraftment. Sputum cultures show Gram-positive cocci in pairs, and she is awaiting speciation.
3. Mixed Metabolic Alkalosis/Respiratory Alkalosis: The patient has a respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation with a RR > 30. The etiology is unclear, and she is being managed with ABGs and titration of ventilation.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has rising creatinine levels and muddy brown casts in the sediment, consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN). She is receiving hemodialysis with removal of 2L of fluid and has received 1 unit of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) after hemodialysis.
5. Atrial Fibrillation (Afib): The patient developed Afib following insertion of the hemodialysis catheter, likely due to atrial irritation. She is being managed with diltiazem.
6. Anemia: The patient has been transfusion-dependent since induction and has received 2 units of pRBCs. Her hemoglobin level has trended down, and she will be rechecked after hemodialysis.
7. Mental Status Changes: The patient has had mental status changes prior to intubation, which may be due to hypoxia and polypharmacy. She will be better evaluated when extubated, and an MRI may be considered if her mental status does not improve.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has bilateral lower lobe infiltrates and ARDS, which may be due to pneumonia.
2. Sinusitis: The patient has a pending CT scan to rule out sinusitis versus new pulmonary process.
3. Re-activation of Pneumonitis: The patient has a history of reactive pneumonitis and may require re-activation of treatment.
4. Volume Overload: The patient has a history of volume overload, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of cardiac disease and may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient has had mental status changes and may be at risk for neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
7. Infectious Complications: The patient has a pending CT scan to rule out sinusitis and may be at risk for other infectious complications, such as bacteremia or sepsis.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 68-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer, post-polio syndrome, and recent diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), fevers, and renal failure.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 102.2F (39C) with spikes, currently 38.1F (100.6C)
* Heart rate: 99 beats per minute (bpm) with a range of 88-129 bpm
* Blood pressure: 157/72 mmHg with a range of 98-163/91 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 27 inspirations per minute (insp/min) with a range of 14-39 insp/min
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus tachycardia

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a pressure support ventilation (PSV) mode, with a tidal volume (Vt) of 396 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 1.1-1.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.7 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 116-127 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.9-3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27-31 mg/dL
* Sodium (Na): 140-148 mmol/L
* Potassium (K): 4.1-4.6 mmol/L
* Chloride (Cl): 103-110 mmol/L
* Carbon dioxide (CO2): 27-31 mmol/L
* Glucose: 81-102 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 508 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 4.6 mg/dL

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and pain management medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Nosocomial influenza
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Infection-related complications
* Hemorrhagic complications due to thrombocytopenia

Given the patient's critical illness, it is essential to closely monitor her condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 68-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer, post-polio syndrome, and recently diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who has been admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure/ARDS, fevers, and renal failure. She has undergone 7+3 chemotherapy and has been receiving treatment for AML.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 102.2F (39C) with a recent spike
* Heart rate: 99 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 157/72 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is not reported.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 1.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 116 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 102 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 81 mg/dL
* Other laboratory results: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and her electrolytes are within normal limits.

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: No new infiltrates
* Computed tomography (CT) scan: To be performed today

The patient's respiratory status is critical, requiring increased support with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 17 cmH2O and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O. The patient is also receiving mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's fever is ongoing, with spikes to 102.2F (39C). She is receiving antibiotics, including levofloxacin, voriconazole, and meropenem. The patient's anemia is being treated with packed red blood cells (pRBCs).

The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) is being managed with hemodialysis (HD), and her anemia is being treated with pRBCs. The patient's acute myeloid leukemia is being followed by the BMT service.

The patient's ICU care includes:

* Nutrition: The patient is receiving a pulmonary nutrition supplement.
* Glycemic control: The patient's blood glucose levels are being monitored and managed.
* Lines: The patient has an arterial line, a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, and a dialysis catheter.
* Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's ongoing fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's AKI is being managed with HD, but further deterioration could lead to chronic kidney disease.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is being treated with pRBCs, but further blood loss or inadequate transfusion could lead to worsening anemia.
* Infections: The patient's ongoing fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of infections, including nosocomial influenza.
* VAP: The patient's respiratory failure and prolonged mechanical ventilation make her susceptible to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension could lead to cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who has undergone induction with 7+3. She is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure, fever, and acute kidney injury (AKI). She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a pressure support (PS) of 10 cmH2O. Her blood cultures are pending, and she has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by ARDS, and she has developed bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. She has also developed a mixed metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis, which is likely due to hyperventilation. Her creatinine has risen, and she has developed muddy brown casts in her urine sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

The patient's mental status has changed, and she is currently sedated. Her hemoglobin has trended down, and she is transfusion-dependent. She has also developed atrial fibrillation (AFib) following the insertion of her hemodialysis (HD) catheter.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is complicated by ARDS, and she may continue to experience respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. AKI: The patient's creatinine has risen, and she has developed muddy brown casts in her urine sediment consistent with ATN. She may require further dialysis to manage her kidney function.
3. Mixed Metabolic Alkalosis and Respiratory Alkalosis: The patient's alkalosis may continue to worsen if not managed properly, leading to complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
4. AFib: The patient's AFib may continue to persist if not managed properly, leading to complications such as stroke and heart failure.
5. Hematological Complications: The patient's hemoglobin has trended down, and she is transfusion-dependent. She may require further transfusions to manage her anemia.
6. Infection: The patient's blood cultures are pending, and she has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. She may continue to be at risk for infection if not managed properly.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiac status is complicated by her AFib and AKI. She may be at risk for cardiac complications such as heart failure and cardiac arrhythmias.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a variety of medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, polio, and newly diagnosed secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who underwent induction with 7+3. She was intubated and developed bilateral lower lobe infiltrates and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). She has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics and has had a negative infectious workup to date. Her condition is complicated by volume overload, pulmonary edema, and a cavitating lesion in the left upper lobe. She has been experiencing fevers, and the differential diagnosis includes infection, re-engraftment, and drug fever. She has also been experiencing respiratory alkalosis and mixed metabolic alkalosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, which increases the risk of developing VAP.
2. Cavitating lesion: The cavitating lesion in the left upper lobe may be a sign of a serious infection, such as tuberculosis, or a complication of the AML.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may be at risk of developing respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fevers and leukopenia may be indicative of sepsis, which can be life-threatening.
5. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are rising, and she may be at risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI).
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac status is uncertain, and she may be at risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as atrial fibrillation or cardiac tamponade.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status is uncertain, and she may be at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is uncertain, and she may be at risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust her ventilator settings as needed.
2. Consider bronchoscopy to evaluate the cavitating lesion and rule out infection.
3. Continue to treat the patient's fevers with broad-spectrum antibiotics and consider switching to targeted therapy if the culture results are negative.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider dialysis if her creatinine levels continue to rise.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider echocardiography to evaluate her cardiac function.
6. Consider gastrointestinal prophylaxis to prevent bleeding or perforation.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider neuroimaging studies to evaluate her neurological function.
8. Continue to communicate with the patient's family and healthcare team to ensure that all parties are aware of the patient's condition and treatment plan.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old female with a history of stage II breast cancer, polio, and post-polio syndrome, who was recently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and started on chemotherapy. She was transferred to the ICU due to progressive hypoxemia, intubated for respiratory failure, and diagnosed with ARDS.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Respiratory failure with ARDS, unknown precipitant, and possible steroid-responsive pneumonitis. She is PEEP-dependent and requires mechanical ventilation.
* Hemodynamic status: Tachycardic with a heart rate of 97 bpm, and hypertension with a blood pressure of 139/70 mmHg.
* Renal status: Acute kidney injury (AKI) with a serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL and a urine output of 165 mL.
* Infectious disease: Fever, with a temperature of 101.6F (38.7C), and negative cultures. She has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including levofloxacin, voriconazole, and meropenem.
* Neurological status: Not assessed due to intubation.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 0.9 K/uL, hemoglobin is 8.3 g/dL, and platelet count is 121 K/uL. Her liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 37 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 13 IU/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, respiratory acidosis, and pulmonary edema.
* ARDS: Prolonged respiratory failure, acute lung injury, and secondary infections.
* AKI: Prolonged dialysis dependence, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of infection.
* Infection: Sepsis, multi-organ failure, and increased risk of mortality.
* Neurological complications: Seizures, cerebral edema, and increased intracranial pressure.
* Hemorrhagic complications: Bleeding diathesis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and intracranial hemorrhage.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, hemodynamic, and renal status. She should continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungal therapy, and her LFTs should be closely monitored. The patient's family should be informed of her critical condition and the potential complications that can arise.

   68 y.o. F with PMHx of Breast CA, polio & newly dx secondary AML s/p
   induction with 7+3.  Post induction course complicated by febrile
   neutropenia, worsening hypoxia & ARDS. Pt transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 44**],
   intubated & s/p Bronchoscopy on [**2167-1-27**].
   # Respiratory Failure
 Pt initially p/w upper lobe PNA, improved on
   Abx. Then, after induction with 7+3 developed bilateral lower lobe
   infiltrates & ARDS, intubated on [**2167-1-27**].  Extensive infectious workup
   has been neg to date, on broad spectrum abx.  [**Month (only) 60**] be [**12-27**] to reactive
   pneumonitis, as it had responded to steroids.  Clinical picture
   complicated by component of volume overload w/ BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 1527**] normal EF,
   but infiltrates not likely [**12-27**] pulm edema alone.  Pt  tolerated PS but
   persistently tachypneic.  Have had difficulty weening from vent due to
   combination of fluid overload and PEEP dependence.   CT scan to
   evaluate worsening of ARDS or development of VAP as patient
s vent
   dependence has increased in the setting of persistent fevers that
   showed cavitating lesion at site of former nodule in left upper lobe.
   Infiltrates improved on the left, worse on the right.  Differential for
   cavitating lesion Infectionus
 TB, staph, klebsiella, anaerobes,
   fungi, amoebiasis; Malig
 bronchial ca v mets; Other
 Wegener
   rheumatoid nodule, pulm infarct, lung abscess, v progressive massive
   fibrosis
   - f/u BAL
   - f/u ANCA for vasculitis work-up, RF negative
   - contact IR to tap pleural effusion as part of diagnostic w/u
   - if unable to obtain diagnostic info, may need to consider section of
   cavitating lesion
   - continue Vancomycin, [**Last Name (un) **], Levo, Vori , Vanc
   - steroids started for reactive pneumonitis now tapered off
   - persistently tachypneic to 50 requiring increase in pressure support
   - continue to work towards extubation, add
l volume removal via HD
   # Fever
  unclear if this is due to new infection vs re-engraftment v
   drug fever.  Sputum GS shows GPC, awaitng speciation, otherwise have
   been NGTD, line site looks good.  CT showed cavitating lesion left
   upper lobe.
   - f/u BAL

   - cont broad spectrum antibiotics
 vanc, voriconazole, [**Last Name (un) 430**] & levo,
   however, in absence of any positive culture data, fevers could be drug
   related, once bronch specimen evaluated, can consider weaning to try to
